{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Rose Lan Pak | native_name = 白兰 | image = Rose Pak, San Francisco's Chinatown 'power broker'.jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = Rose Pak in 1999 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date|1947|11|25}} | birth_place = Hunan, China | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|09|18|1947|11|25}} | death_place = San Francisco, California | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = journalist, political activist | years_active = 1972–2016 | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Rose Lan Pak''' ({{zh|c=白兰|p=báilán|j=Baak6 Laan4}})<ref name=":2"/> was a [[activism|political activist]] in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], noted for her advocacy for the [[Chinatown, San Francisco|Chinatown]] community and her influence on city politics.<ref name="Wildermuth">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Chinatown-s-champion-3173928.php|title=Chinatown's Champion|first=John|date=September 19, 2010|work=[[SFGate.com]]|publisher=[[Hearst Newspapers]]|author=Wildermuth|accessdate=May 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.modernluxury.com/san-francisco/story/rose-pak-regrets|title=A Gravely Ill Rose Pak on Life, Death, and Her Greatest Regret (the Mayor)|date=August 20, 2015|website=www.modernluxury.com|language=en-US|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> Pak served as a consultant for the San Francisco Chinese Chamber of Commerce and organizer of the [[San Francisco Chinese New Year Festival and Parade|Chinese New Year Parade in San Francisco]].<ref name=Wildermuth/> Although Pak never held an elective political office, she was known as an outspoken and well-connected "gatekeeper" figure who supported politicians by raising funds and connecting them with the city's growing Asian American community.<ref name=":7" />
==Early life== Pak was born in [[Hunan]], China, on November 27, 1947.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://obits.dignitymemorial.com/dignity-memorial/obituary.aspx?n=Rose-Pak&lc=2594&pid=181481914&mid=7096214|title=Rose Pak Obituary - Green Street Mortuary {{!}} San Francisco CA|website=obits.dignitymemorial.com|access-date=2016-09-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160921044253/http://obits.dignitymemorial.com/dignity-memorial/obituary.aspx?n=Rose-Pak&lc=2594&pid=181481914&mid=7096214|archivedate=September 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She received a Catholic education while growing up as a refugee in Macau and Hong Kong after her father, a businessman, had died in the [[Chinese Civil War]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/12/us/rose-pak-a-chinatown-power-broker-savors-mayor-edwin-lees-victory.html|title=Rose Pak, a Chinatown Power Broker, Savors Mayor Edwin Lee’s Victory|last=Eckholm|first=Erik|date=November 11, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref> When she was 17, she received a scholarship to attend the [[San Francisco College for Women]], and in 1972 earned a master's degree at the [[Columbia School of Journalism]].<ref name="Wildermuth" /><ref name=":4" /> After a brief stint working at ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{Citation|last=FORA.tv|title=The New West with Will Hearst: Rose Pak|date=July 18, 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=weMse1zMHTg&t=261|accessdate=September 19, 2016}}</ref> she returned to San Francisco to work for the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' (as its first female Asian American journalist<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfbos.org/ftp/uploadedfiles/bdsupvrs/resolutions16/r0128-16.pdf|title=Resolution 128-16: Rename James Alley to 'Rose Pak's Way 白蘭之道'|last=|first=|date=April 22, 2016|website=|publisher=San Francisco Board of Supervisors|access-date=}}</ref>), a job that she left after eight years to become a full-time social activist.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" />
==Political career== Pak's first objective as an activist was to organize a campaign to save the [[San Francisco Chinese Hospital]] from closure.<ref name=":3" /> Later she worked for decades to advocate for its replacement by a new, modern building, and for the [[Central Subway]] project that is set to improve Chinatown's connection to the rest of the Bay Area.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/epaper/2014-01/24/content_17256194.htm|title=Rose Pak: A tireless advocate for Chinatown|last=Jun|first=Chang|date=January 24, 2014|website=|publisher=[[China Daily]]|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref> Both projects broke ground in 2013.<ref name=":5" />
Pak was a supporter of [[Art Agnos]] (the city's mayor from 1988 to 1992), but opposed his efforts to tear down the [[Embarcadero Freeway]], arguing that Chinatown would suffer catastrophic consequences if it lost the fast crosstown connection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Chinatown-s-champion-3173928.php|title=Chinatown's champion|last=Wildermuth|first=John|date=September 19, 2009|website=|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref> She won a ballot measure about the issue in 1987, but after the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake]] damaged the freeway, her objections were overturned.<ref name="Wildermuth" /> According to the San Francisco Chronicle, Pak then "almost single-handedly persuaded the city to build" the $1.5 billion Central Subway project to compensate Chinatown for the demolition of the freeway.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/matier-ross/article/Rose-Pak-flashes-red-light-on-Stockton-Street-9126204.php|title=Rose Pak flashes red light on Stockton Street pedestrian mall|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=San Francisco Chonicle|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref>
In 2011, Pak was instrumental in obtaining consensus to nominate [[Ed Lee (politician)|Edwin M. Lee]] as the first [[Asian American]] mayor of San Francisco.<ref name=":4">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/12/us/rose-pak-a-chinatown-power-broker-savors-mayor-edwin-lees-victory.html?pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first=Erik | last=Eckholm | title=Rose Pak, a Chinatown Power Broker, Savors Mayor Edwin Lee's Victory | date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> Pak said, "This was finally our moment to make the first Chinese mayor of a major city."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/07/us/07bcmayor.html| title=Behind-the-Scenes Power Politics: The Making of a Mayor| author=Gerry Shih | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=January 6, 2011 | accessdate=January 7, 2010}}</ref>
In 2015, Pak and her ally Ed Lee had a fallout over Lee's choice of [[Julie Christensen (politician)|Julie Christensen]] as a replacement appointment to the Board of Supervisor instead of Pak's protege Cindy Wu.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/matier-ross/article/S-F-Mayor-Ed-Lee-gets-fat-donation-earful-from-6013221.php|title=S.F. Mayor Ed Lee gets fat donation, earful from ally Rose Pak|date=January 14, 2015|website=SFGate|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> Pak went on to support her former longtime adversary [[Aaron Peskin]] against Christensen in the supervisor elections for District 3 (which includes Chinatown) later that year.<ref name=":0" /> Peskin defeated Christensen.
Shortly before her death in 2016, Pak vehemently opposed a project to permanently convert parts of [[Stockton Street (San Francisco)|Stockton Street]] in the Union Square area outside of Chinatown into a pedestrian zone, arguing that Stockton Street was a "vital link" for Chinatown, and threatening to organize a blockade of City Hall by thousands of vehicles if the idea came to pass.<ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2016/08/08/rose-pak-threatens-city-hall-blockade-over-stockton-street-proposal/|title=Rose Pak Threatens City Hall Blockade Over Stockton Street Proposal|last=Matier|first=Phil|date=August 8, 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref>
[[File:0182 Rose Pak Way (40885750874).jpg|thumb|right|Rose Pak's Way]] On the reopening of the Chinese Hospital at the end of April 2016, the city renamed an alley in Chinatown just east of the new tower in her honor to "Rose Pak's Way 白蘭之道".<ref name=":6" /> In May 2016, Pak returned to San Francisco after an extended medical stay in China where she had received a [[Kidney transplantation|kidney transplant]], announcing to a welcoming committee of Chinatown elders, local politicians and city officials that her health had been restored.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://sfist.com/2016/05/23/rose_pak_returns_following_extended.php|title=Rose Pak Returns Following Extended Medical Stay In China|last=Barmann|first=Jay|date=May 23, 2016|website=SFist|access-date=May 24, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160526084402/http://sfist.com/2016/05/23/rose_pak_returns_following_extended.php|archivedate=May 26, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/rose-pak-back-feinstein-swipes-airbnb/|title=Rose Pak is back; Feinstein swipes at Airbnb (again)|last=Rodriguez|first=Joe Fitzgerald|date=May 23, 2016|website=The San Francisco Examiner|language=en-US|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> She died in San Francisco on September 18, 2016, aged 68.<ref name=":7">{{cite news|title=Rose Pak, SF political powerhouse, dies|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/article/Rose-Pak-SF-political-powerhouse-dies-9230594.php?t=59ea95ca71|accessdate=September 19, 2016|work=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> She was single all of her life, and had no children.<ref name=":7" />
=== Political ties to the People's Republic of China === Pak was an overseas executive director of the China Overseas Exchange Association (COEA), an organization overseen by the [[Overseas Chinese Affairs Office]] (OCAO) of the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://foreignpolicyblogs.com/2016/06/09/beijing-hidden-influence-san-francisco/|title=Beijing-by-the-Bay: China's Hidden Influence in San Francisco|last=Eades|first=Mark C.|date=June 9, 2016|website=Foreign Policy Blogs|publisher=|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref> At various times she spoke out in favor of the Chinese government's views, e.g. in 2012 calling all "overseas Chinese" to "defend the homeland” in the conflict about the [[Senkaku Islands|Diaoyu Islands]], and in 2008 opposing a resolution of the SF Board of Supervisors that criticized China for the Tiananmen Square massacre and other repression measures, passed on occasion of the [[2008 Summer Olympics torch relay|Beijing Summer Olympics torch relay]] reaching San Francisco.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/apr/02/local/me-torch2|title=S.F. keeping a light on for China? Not exactly|last=Glionna|first=John M.|date=April 2, 2008|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=September 19, 2016}}</ref>
Pak was critical of the [[Falun Gong]] movement in San Francisco and in 2004 she banned the group from participating in the city's annual Chinese New Year's Parade.<ref name="Wildermuth" /> The group and others, including San Francisco Supervisor [[Chris Daly]], subsequently alleged that Pak had connections to the Chinese Communist Party.<ref name="Wildermuth" /> Pak consistently denied any ties with Beijing.<ref name="Wildermuth" /> In an August 2011 interview with the [[New Tang Dynasty Television]] and ''[[Epoch Times]]'', former San Francisco Board of Supervisors President [[Aaron Peskin]] made similar allegations, claiming that Pak was "the real leader of San Francisco", and that she represented outside governmental interests that "include the People's Republic of China."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/united-states/san-francisco-mayoral-race-deeply-corrupted-says-former-legislator-60506.html|title=San Francisco Mayoral Race Deeply Corrupted, Says Former Legislator|date=August 17, 2011|work=[[The Epoch Times]]|author=Matthew Robertson|accessdate=August 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sf.ntdtv.com/video/?id=na574200&&start=20|title=誰在操縱市長選舉 (Chinese video - Who's controlling the Mayoral Election)|date=August 16, 2011|work=[[New Tang Dynasty Television]]|accessdate=August 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425123400/http://www.sf.ntdtv.com/video/?id=na574200&&start=20|archivedate=April 25, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|Asian Americans|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[History of the Chinese Americans in San Francisco]] {{clear}}

'''Rafael Vásquez''' (1804–1854) was a 19th-century general in the Mexican Army during the Mexican rebellion against the centralist style rule of government.
==Early life== Vásquez was born in Mexico City in 1804. His first military endeavor was on February 20, 1827, as Captain of Patriots of the Hacienda de Ciénega de Mata, [[Jalisco, Mexico]]. He was appointed brevet brigadier general in 1839.
==Mexican political rebellions== Vásquez was a major figure in the suppression of the Mexican insurgents, who opposed the centralization of the Mexican government under General [[Antonio López de Santa Anna]]. The states of [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[Tamaulipas]] had advocated rebellion and sought secession from Mexico and declared a new [[Republic of the Rio Grande]].<ref>David M. Vigness, "REPUBLIC OF THE RIO GRANDE," Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ngr01], accessed September 23, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref> Vásquez led a force to subdue [[Antonio Canales Rosillo]] and his Texan - Mexican troops into an ambush near [[Saltillo, Mexico]].<ref>Roberto Mario Salmón, "CANALES ROSILLO, ANTONIO," Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fca38], accessed September 23, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref> Assisting Canales was Colonel Samuel W. Jordan. Jordan led a group of federalist troops that had secretly been infiltrated by centralist supporters. However, he still managed to rout the centralists forces who quickly fled to Saltillo.<ref>"JORDAN, SAMUEL W.," Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fjo73], accessed September 23, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref>
==Texas invasion== On March 5, 1842, General Vásquez invaded Texas with about 700 men and occupied [[San Antonio, Texas]]. The Texan forces were surprised and overwhelmed.<ref name="de la Teja116">de la Teja (1991), p. 116.</ref> After a few skirmishes, they were unable to defend the town and evacuated to [[Seguin, Texas]]. Vásquez deemed it a surrender and took control of San Antonio. He raised the Mexican flag and thus declared Mexican laws in effect. On March 7, Vásquez fled San Antonio, while pursued by Texan forces.<ref name="de la Teja117">de la Teja (1991), p. 117.</ref> He crossed the Rio Grande and returned to Mexico. The Vásquez expedition was one of the events that led to retaliations by the Texans through the [[Mier Expedition]] and [[Somervell Expedition]].
==Later life== Later in 1851 and 1852, Vásquez was commandant general of the state of [[Jalisco, Mexico]] . He died on March 9, 1854, in Mexico City.<ref>"VASQUEZ, RAFAEL," Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fva22], accessed September 23, 2011. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref>
==Citations== <references /> ==References== *{{Cite book|last=De la Teja|first=Jesus|title=A Revolution Remembered: The Memoirs and Selected Correspondence of Juan N. Seguin|publisher=State House Press|location=Austin, TX|year=1991|isbn=0-938349-68-6}}

'''Saket Modi''' (''ca.'' 1990/91<ref name="si">{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconindia.com/news/enterpriseit/Saket-Modi-The-22-Yr-Old-Who-Saves-RBI-From-Deadly-Hackers--nid-145705-cid-7.html|title=Saket Modi, The 22 Yr Old Who Saves Govt Agencies From Deadly Hackers|author=|date=22 April 2013|work=SiliconIndia|accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref>) is the Co-founder and CEO of [[Lucideus]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Saket Modi's Lucideus ensures your system is protected from threats that you did not even know existed|url=http://forbesindia.com/article/work/apping-it-what-the-techpreneurs-are-fiddling-with/38851/1|newspaper=Forbes|date=1 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Apping it: What the tech-preneurs are fiddling with|url=http://entrepreneurindia.in/start-ups/saket-modis-venture-lucideus-works-towards-protecting-various-companies-content-from-getting-hacked/21502/|newspaper=The Entrepreneur Magazine|date=13 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010013730/http://entrepreneurindia.in/start-ups/saket-modis-venture-lucideus-works-towards-protecting-various-companies-content-from-getting-hacked/21502/|archivedate=10 October 2013|df=}}</ref>, an enterprise cyber security platforms company<ref>{{cite web|title=Lucideus set to grow into a billion dollar cyber security|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/special-videos/lucideus-set-to-grow-intobillion-dollar-cyber-security_952068.html|work=CNBC TV 18|date=23 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Delhi-based cyber security firm Lucideus battles hackers |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-19/news/38674331_1_cyber-fraud-security-high-end-products |newspaper=The Economic Times|date=19 April 2013}}</ref>. A computer science engineer by education, he founded [[Lucideus]] in 2012 while in his final year of engineering. Incubated from [[Indian Institute of Technology Bombay|IIT Bombay]] and backed by [[Cisco Systems|Cisco's]] former Chairman and CEO [[John T. Chambers|John Chambers]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fortuneindia.com/technology/breaking-the-cyber-web/102624|title=Why John Chambers loves Saket Modi’s Lucideus|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en}}</ref>, [[Lucideus]] today protects multiple [[Fortune 500]] companies around the world with it's cyber risk measurement and mitigation platform called SAFE<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lucideus.com/safe.html|title=SAFE {{!}} Security Assessment Framework for Enterprise {{!}} Cyber Security Products|website=www.lucideus.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>. The product was recognized among the Top Innovations of the Year<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbesindia.com/innovation-nation/1701/1|title=Innovation Nation : Special Report : Forbes India Magazine|website=Forbes India|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> by [[Forbes|Forbes Magazine]] in 2018. Saket is a part of [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune Magazine's]] 40under40<ref name=":2" />, [[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur Magazine's]] 35under35<ref name=":1" />, [[Forbes|Forbes Magazine's]] 30under30<ref name=":0" /> lists among others. The [[Government of India]] awarded him with the title of Champion of Change<ref name=":3" /> in 2017.
==Early life==
Saket was born and raised in [[Kolkata|Kolkata (Calcutta)]]. In the year 2009, he joined the [[LNM Institute of Information Technology]], for engineering as a computer science major. He completed early schooling from [[Lakshmipat Singhania Academy]]. Before starting [[Lucideus]] in 2012, Saket initiated his career by giving seminars and workshops on ethical hacking and cyber forensics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://heyevent.com/event/y7loclumrnwxsa/free-ethical-hacking-seminar-by-mr-saket-modi|title=FREE ETHICAL HACKING SEMINAR by Mr. Saket Modi – Heyevent.com|website=heyevent.com|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Indian cybersecurity startup counts on being street smart, hands on|url=http://www.zdnet.com/in/indian-cybersecurity-startup-counts-on-being-street-smart-hands-on-7000014434/|work=ZDNet|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Careers for an Ethical Hacker|url=http://lucideus.com/news/articles/ananda_bazaar_patrika_lucideus_story.jpg|newspaper=Ananda Bazar Patrika|date=27 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140213195344/http://lucideus.com/news/articles/ananda_bazaar_patrika_lucideus_story.jpg|archivedate=2014-02-13|df=}}</ref> His workshops gradually became popular, as a result of which he was invited to over a hundred colleges across the globe.<ref name="lu">{{cite web|title = Top Management Team of Lucideus|url = http://lucideus.com/leaders-1.html}}</ref> Some of the major Institutions who have hosted his workshops include [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|UIUC]], [[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur|IIT Kanpur]], [[Indian Institute of Technology Bombay|IIT Bombay]], [[Indian Institute of Technology Delhi|IIT Delhi]], [[Birla Institute of Technology and Science|BITS Pilani]], [[Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati|IIT Guwahati]] among others.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saket Modi explaining explains the impact of the rise of NextGen malware analysis within ethical hacking|url=http://www.educationtimes.com/article/269/201305272013052518363410660a439d1/Finding-loopholes.html|newspaper=The Education Times|date=27 May 2013}}</ref> He led the team that developed the smartphone privacy app UnHack in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yjcqto5C6Ak|title=CNBC: Tech Guru - Mobile Phone Hacks|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessworld.in/news/business/it/www-the-hackers%E2%80%99-haven/1707848/page-1.html|title=WWW - a Hackers Haven|date=25 January 2015|newspaper=Business {{multiple issues| {{advert|date=July 2017}} {{primary sources|date=July 2017}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Shyamal-Saumil | background = group_or_band | image = | image_size = 250 | caption = | origin = [[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]], India. | genre = {{hlist|[[Sugam Sangeet|Classical Indian]]|[[Gujarati pop]]}} | years_active = 1980-present | label = {{hlist|[[Wonder Waves]]|}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Tushar Shukla]]|[[Malove Divatia]]|[[Maati Baani]]|[[Jagjit Singh]]|[[Shankar Mahadevan]]|[[Udit Narayan]]}} | website = {{URL|shyamalsaumil.com}} | current_members = *[[Saumil Munshi]] *[[Shyamal Munshi]] *[[Aarti Munshi]] }}'''Shyamal-Saumil''' is an [[Indian classical music]] duo formed in 1980, in [[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]], India, composed of the Gujarati singers, Dr. Shyamal Munshi and Saumil Munshi. Shyamal-Saumil achieved both critical acclaim and commercial success in the 1980s and early 1990s, helping to popularize Gujarati classical music, known as "Sugam Sangeet" while experimenting, innovating, and branching out into other forms of media, like cinema and theatre. Shyamal-Saumil are known for their inclusive music, having created a plethora of albums for children, adolescents, and adults, and also having delved into and having explored different cultures and religious folk music in their works.
== History == Saumil Munshi was born on the 5th of September, 1960, while Shyamal Munshi was born on 14 April 1962, in Ahmedabad, India, to their father Paresh Munshi and mother Bhaktida Munshi. The passion for music and literature was instilled at a young age by their school activities. The two used to go to performances and competitions, where they used to recite ghazals and poems. In 1973, they joined the Jagh Mag Mandal, where they used to perform a variety of music, from film songs to classical poetry.
=== 1980–1984: Formation and debut === In 1980, the two gave their debut organized solo performance, titled, "Morpichch", a sold-out show. The show launched their careers and gave them credibility and fame. The shows were repeated in [[Kolkata]] and [[Mumbai]] as well, and over the course of the first 5 years, they gave 20 shows in 3 cities.
=== 1984-2000: Performances, Meghdhanoosh, and Acclaim === In 1995, Shyamal-Saumil released Meghdhanoosh, initially in cassette form, dedicated entirely to kids. The album comprised 45 songs on different morals and themes, and was largely sung by kids themselves. To this date, Meghdhanoosh remains the duo's best-selling album, selling over 25,000 copies.
=== 2000-2002: Further Success and Swarsetu === Having earned fame and success, Shyamal-Saumil, in late 2000, launched "Swarsetu", a listeners forum, to promote "Sugam Sangeet" and "Kavya Sangeet", as well as to introduce new and upcoming artists while staying true to the culture. Since 2000, Shyamal-Saumil have organized over 90 performances, each with a different theme and message. Swarsetu also allows children and adolescents to showcase their talents and imbibe roots and foundations into them.
=== 2002-2005: Hastakshar and Critical Reception === in 2002, Shyamal-Saumil released the biggest collaborative project of their career, a 6-album project called, "Hastakshar", with each album containing songs by a different illustrious poet and lyricist. These poets were Tushar Shukla, Raman Patel, [[Ramesh Parekh]], [[Suresh Dalal]], and [[Umashankar Joshi]], and for their songs, Shyamal-Saumil brought together 30 artists to create the project. The title song was sung by [[Jagjit Singh]], and other famous Bollywood singers also gave their voices for the songs. These included [[Kavita Krishnamurthy]], [[Shankar Mahadevan]], [[Udit Narayan]], [[Sadhana Sargam]],Bhupendar Singh, and Shubha Joshi. [[Shreya Ghoshal|Shreya Goshal]] sang her first Gujarati song on the album's track, "Aaj Maaru Mann". The album was extolled for its versatility and its richness in quality.
=== 2005-Present: Anushthaan, Swarsetu, and Legacy === In 2012, the Swarsetu News Digest was launched by Shyamal-Saumil, a monthly magazine, which showcased art, literature, music, poetry, and drama in Gujarat. The magazine also invited famous authors and poets to write columns, and was catered for all ages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shyamalsaumil.com/swarsetu-news-digest/|title=Swarsetu News Digest {{!}} Shyamal Saumil|last=shyamalsaumil.com|website=www.shyamalsaumil.com|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref> Since then, the magazine has also launched several competitions and literature fests, and workshops are organized in several schools to help propagate Gujarati culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/udgamschool/posts/10156246459865713|title=Udgam School for Children|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
Aapnu Amdavad Surilu Amdavad was a project released in 2011 to celebrate the heritage of the city of Ahmedabad. All the songs in the album were accompanied with videos, making the album one of the first music video albums in Gujarati music. The videos had notable appearances by the then-Mayor of Ahmedabad, [[Asit Vora]], and Indian cricketer, [[Parthiv Patel]], and also featured songs dedicated to the festival of kites, [[International Kite Festival in Gujarat – Uttarayan|Uttarayan]], and to [[Manek Chowk (Ahmedabad)|Manekchowk]], a prominent city square in Ahmedabad.
In 2014, Shyamal-Saumil organized a 3-day music festival called Anushthaan, an event which the Times of India called a "spectacle for music-lovers."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/gujarati/music/Amdavadis-all-set-for-Anushthan/articleshow/45492438.cms|title=Amdavadis all set for Anushthan - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref> The event featured artists from all around Gujarat, including Parthiv Gohil, [[Aishwarya Majmudar|Aishwariya Majmudar]], Hema Desai, Dipali Somaiyya, and nearly 50 other musicians and artists. In 2015 and 2016, the event was repeated with further critical acclaim and success, and featured a plethora of artists, a lineup which included Maati Baani, [[Bhoomi Trivedi]], Osman Mir, Aalap Desai, Aashit Desai, the Tabla Taalim Sanstha, Rhythm Pulze, and nearly 80 other artists. The events also included dance performances by Chandan and Nirali Thakore, Maulik and Ishira Shah. Being an ensemble of the arts, Anushthaan also included several poets, stand-up comedians, and actors, who gave talks, speeches, and performances. Renowned artists like Sairam Dave, [[Jay Vasavada|Jay Vasavda]], [[Dhvanit Thaker|RJ Dhvanit]], Tushar Shukla, [[Darshan Jariwala]], [[Harsh Brahmbhatt]], Archan Trivedi, and [[Abhishek Jain]] were among the celebrities present. In 2015, the event featured Gujarat's first LED floor, and in 2016, the very first Gujarati a cappella performance was presented. New techniques like projection mapping and optical illusion dances were also performed.
== Collaborations == With Red FM, Shyamal Saumil produced 4 albums, focusing mainly on garba, while also fusing Gujarati pop with traditional folk. These albums are: * Bajate Raho Beshaq Bindass * Red Raas Garba Vol. 1 * Red Raas Garba Vol. 2 * Red Raas Garba Vol. 3
== Film projects == Shyamal-Saumil have lent their music for several films, of which, Bhale Padharya won them the Cine-Aishwariya Best Music Director Award. * Bhale Padharya: Welcome to Gujarat (2011) * [[Mission Mummy]] * Hun Hunshi Hunshi Laal Apart from cinema, the duo have also produced music and have sung for several TV Shows, which include: * Vaanarsena * Grahan * Maare Pann Ek Ghar Hoy * Ramat Ramaade Ramo * Kalrav na Koyda (with Doordarshan)
== Discography == ; Studio Albums Throughout the span of their 37-year career, Shyamal-Saumil have produced a total of 21 albums. These albums follow distinct themes, and are thus split into 4 categories.
Chanchal<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shyamalsaumil.com/product-category/chanchal/|title=Chanchal {{!}} Shyamal Saumil|last=shyamalsaumil.com|website=www.shyamalsaumil.com|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
The albums under this category are typically for adolescents and young adults. These include: * Rangtaal (2005) * Aapnun Amdavad Surilun Amdavad (2012) * Aasneh (2014) Sheetal
The "Sheetal" category of albums comprises ghazals and more poetic pieces, and these cover a wide range of themes. Albums under this section include: * Aabshaar (2016) * Mara Hissa No Suraj (2016) * Meh Jharmar (2014) * Swarsaavan (2014) * Swarkavan (2013) * Rajuat (2011) * [[Morpichch]] (2005) * [[Hastakshar]] (2002) Nirmal<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shyamalsaumil.com/product-category/nirmal/|title=Nirmal {{!}} Shyamal Saumil|last=shyamalsaumil.com|website=www.shyamalsaumil.com|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
Consisting of devotional songs and songs of worship, the Nirmal category has the following albums: * Shiv Dhoon (2013) * Shivmahim Stotram (2013) * Bhavsarita (2006) * Maha Mantra (2005) * Dhoon (2002) * Jin Vandana (2000) * Jin Mangal (1998) Komal<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shyamalsaumil.com/product-category/komal/|title=Komal {{!}} Shyamal Saumil|last=shyamalsaumil.com|website=www.shyamalsaumil.com|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
An entire section dedicated to children, the songs under this section usually carry a message or a moral, and are often sung by children themselves. The albums include: * Tim Tim Taara (2014) * [[Allak Mallak]] (2005) * [[Meghdhanoosh]] (1999)

'''Stephen J. Suomi''' is chief of the Laboratory of Comparative Ethology at the [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] (NICHD) in Bethesda, Maryland. He is also a research professor at the [[University of Virginia]], the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]], and [[Johns Hopkins University]]. He is involved with the Experience-based Brain & Biological Development Program, launched in 2003 by the [[Canadian Institute for Advanced Research]].<ref name=profile>[http://ciar.ca/web/home.nsf/pages/home.0673 "Profile for Stephen Suomi"], Canadian Institute for Advanced Research.</ref>
Suomi was elected as a Fellow of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] for his contributions to the understanding of how socialization affects the psychological development of non-human [[primates]].<ref name=profile/> He worked in the early 1970s as a research assistant to psychologist Harry Harlow, showing that it was possible to rehabilitate rhesus monkeys that had been reared in social isolation for the first six months of life by temporarily housing them with socially normal monkeys. At the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]] Suomi worked with [[Harry Harlow]] to develop the [[pit of despair]], a series of controversial and widely condemned experiments on baby monkeys that have been credited by some researchers as starting the [[animal liberation movement]] in the United States.<ref name="Blum2002/225">Blum, Deborah. ''Love at Goon Park: Harry Harlow and the Science of Affection''. Perseus Publishing, 2002, p. 225.</ref> Suomi has made no mention of the morality of his work.
==Education and career== Suomi received a B.A. in psychology from [[Stanford University]] in 1968, and a Ph.D. in the same subject from the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] in 1971. He became a full professor with the university's psychology department in 1984, and began to work for the NICHD in 1983.<ref name=profile/>
==Work== Suomi describes his current research interests as focusing on the role of genetic and environmental factors in shaping individual psychological development in non-human primates; the effect of change on psychological development; and whether findings on monkeys in captivity can translate to monkeys living in the wild, and between human beings of different cultures.<ref name=profile/>
A former Harry Harlow student, Suomi has been criticized by members of the U.S. Congress for maternal deprivation experiments on monkeys.
